biblStruct.note: received January 29, 2018; revised April 18, 2018; accepted May 9, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper addresses the finite-time bipartite consensus problem for multi-agent systems (MASs) on a directed signed network. Some properties for signed digraphs are first investigated and two nonlinear control protocols are then designed for first-and second-order MASs, respectively, where agents may be influenced by bounded disturbances. Particularly, for MASs with second-order dynamics, a new estimation technique is developed to estimate the settling time. Simulation results are finally presented to verify the effectiveness of the proposed control protocols.

Among the topics of cooperative control, consensus problem is the most popular and also a fundamental one, which aims to manipulate the states of all the agents to reach an agreement by designing some cooperative protocols based on relative local information for arbitrary initial conditions [3]- [12]. However, one may observe that most existing works on the consensus problem are obtained based on the assumption that the relationships or interactions among the agents are all cooperative, with no conflict or competition, which leads to the nonnegativity of the weights in their communication topology. While in reality, there are counterexamples in social networks [13], [14], such as two-party political systems, trust networks [15], [16] and so on, where the interactions may be antagonistic. To explore these phenomena, an increasing number of works focused on the collective dynamics emerging with such kind of interactions called the cluster synchronization [17]- [21]. Actually, such situations can be described as networks with antagonistic interactions, which can be represented by a class of signed graphs [22] whose weights could be either positive or negative. Recently, a particularly interesting problem of cluster synchronization has been raised in [23] called bipartite consensus, which means that the states of the agents reach an agreement in terms of modulus but not sign.

It is generally known that a transformation of coordinates can bridge the bipartite consensus and the usual consensus where no competition exists. In [23], bipartite consensus was investigated for first-order multi-agent systems on both undirected and directed signed graphs, where the convergence rate is asymptotic. In [24], the bipartite consensus problem for a class of linear systems was studied on undirected digraphs with asymptotic convergence rate. The work of [25] extended the bipartite consensus into a more general setting, called the interval bipartite consensus, for which the topological condition was relaxed. Reference [26] further investigated the bipartite containment tracking without requiring the spanning tree condition, which generalized the interval bipartite consensus result. In all such studies, convergence rate is an important measure for evaluating a proposed control protocol from practical considerations. Finite-time consensus protocols have better system performance with faster convergence rates and other merits such as effective disturbance rejection [27]. The finite-time bipartite consensus problem for first-order multi-agents was investigated on a class of undirected signed graphs in [28] and [29]. As for usual consensus (which can be easily transfered to bipartite consensus), [30] and [31] considered the finite-time consensus problem for first-order multi-agents under undirected and directed graphs. Reference [32] considered both finite-time and fixed-time multiscale coordination for first-order multi-agents under undirected graphs. Besides, the finite-time bipartite consensus problem on directed signed graphs with higher-order dynamics still remains unsolved. The difficulty for solving such a problem partly lies in the facts that the communication over a signed directed graph is asymmetric. Furthermore, even in the usual finite-time consensus problems of higher-order multi-agent systems [33]- [41], the convergence time estimation is not easy to obtain. Besides, the topologies considered (in tracking problem, referred to topologies among followers) were detailed balanced in [33] and [34], and undirected in [35]- [41].

Motivated by the above discussions, this paper investigates the finite-time bipartite consensus problem on directed signed graphs for both first-and second-order multi-agent systems, where the agents may be influenced by bounded disturbances. The main contributions of this work are twofold. First, a positive lower bound for a special quadratic form constructed from Lyapunov function is obtained, based on which, the finitetime first-and second-order bipartite consensus without any leader are solved. One should notice that most existing relevant results are finite-time tracking consensus and finite-time leaderless consensus is more difficult. Besides, the finitetime first-order bipartite consensus of the considered MASs is extended to the fixed-time bipartite consensus, in which the bound of the convergence time is independent of the initial conditions. Second, the homogeneous technique is utilized to solve the finite-time bipartite consensus problem for secondorder multi-agents. Interestingly, the settling time is not trivial to estimate by the usual homogeneous theory [41], but can be well estimated by the proposed technique.

The rest of the paper is arranged as follows. Some basic concepts about signed graphs and some useful lemmas are presented in Section II. The finite-time first-and second-order bipartite consensus problems are discussed in Sections III and IV, respectively. In Section V, some simulations are given to verify the theoretical analysis. Finally, conclusion is drawn in Section VI.

Notations: x [α] sign(x)|x| α , x ∈ R, α > 0. When x is a vector, the function (•) [α] operates on it componentwise. Re(λ) takes the real part of λ ∈ C, where C is the set of complex numbers. λ min (B) (λ max (B)) means the minimal (maximal) eigenvalue of the symmetric real matrix B. O(x, r ) means the open ball centered at x ∈ R N with radius r > 0. Furthermore, 0 1×N (0 N×1 ) means an N-dimensional row (column) vector with all elements being 0. Two matrices A, B ∈ R N×N are called similar if B = P -1 A P for some invertible matrix P ∈ R N×N , and is denoted by A ∼ B. Denote diag(a 1 , ..., a k ) as a diagonal matrix with its diagonal elements being a i , where a i ∈ R, i = 1, ..., k.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In this section, some basic concepts about signed graph and preliminary results on finite-time consensus are introduced.

A signed graph G = (V, E, G) involves a set of nodes V = {v 1 , v 2 , ..., v N }, a set of edges E ⊆ V × V and a signed weighted adjacency matrix G = (G i j ) N×N . Here, an edge E i j in E means a pair of nodes (v j , v i ) representing that the information flow goes from node v j to node v i . G records the coupling configuration of all edges in G. The signed weight G i j , which can be either positive or negative, is defined as:
div.formula: G i j = 0 ⇔ (v j , v i ) ∈ E. In this paper, self-loop is not considered, i.e. G ii = 0, i = 1, 2, ..., N. The graph G is undirected if (v i , v j ) ∈ E implies (v j , v i ) ∈ E, and G T = G; otherwise G is called a directed graph (digraph).
div.p: Remark 1: In the following, an edge (a path/cycle) is always referred to an edge (a path/cycle) in a signed graph, unless otherwise indicated. A graph with nonnegative weights is called a positive graph, which is a special case of a signed graph.
Definition 1 [23], [42]:
div.formula: A directed path from node v j to v i is a sequence of directed edges, (v i ,v i 1 ), (v i 1 ,v i 2 ),..., (v i l ,v j ), in the directed network with distinct nodes v i k , k = 1, 2, ..., l.
div.p: A directed network G is strongly connected if between any pair of distinct nodes v i and v j in G, there exists a directed path, i, j = 1, 2, ..., N. A directed cycle is a directed path beginning from and ending at the same node. A directed cycle is positive if the product of all its signed edge weights is positive; otherwise, it is negative.
The Laplacian matrix L = (l i j ) N×N for a signed graph G is denoted by [23]
div.formula: l ii = N j =1, j =i |G i j |; l i j = -G i j , i = j.
div.p: Lemma 1 [7], [54]: Suppose that G is a positive and strongly connected graph. Then, 0 is the algebraically simple eigenvalue of its Laplacian L, and the other eigenvalues have positive real parts. If the positive graph is undirected and connected, L has one zero eigenvalue and the others are all real and positive.
Definition 2 [23]: A signed graph G is said to be structurally balanced if it admits a bipartition of the nodes,
div.formula: V 1 and V 2 , satisfying V 1 V 2 = V and V 1 V 2 = 0, such that G i j ≥ 0, v i , v j ∈ V q (q ∈ {1, 2}), and G i j ≤ 0, v i ∈ V q , v j ∈ V 3-q (q ∈ {1, 2}). Otherwise, it is called structurally unbalanced. Define D = {D = diag(d 1 , d 2 , ..., d N ), d i ∈ {±1}}.
div.p: Then, the following Lemma 2 show some equivalent conditions for structural balance.
Lemma 2 [23]: A strongly connected signed digraph G (of order N) is structurally balanced if and only if any of the following condition holds:
1) all directed cycles of G are positive; 2) ∃D ∈ D such that DG D has all nonnegative entries; 3) 0 is an eigenvalue of L, and rank(L) = N -1.

Remark 2 As for structural unbalance, one can obtain the corresponding equivalent conditions by negating these three conditions. For example, Since L is diagonally dominant, the corresponding equivalent condition 3) should be: -L is Hurwitz stable.
In the following, two useful lemmas about positive directed graphs are provided.

Lemma 3 [42], [44]: Consider a strongly connected positive graph, with the corresponding Laplacian matrix L p . Then, L p 1 N = 0, and there is a positive vector ξ p = (ξ p1 , ξ p2 , ..., ξ pN ) T such that ξ T p L p = 0. Lemma 4 [42], [54]: For a strongly connected positive graph with Laplacian matrix L p , define its general algebraic connectivity by
div.formula: a(L p ) = min x T ξ p =0,x =0 x T L p x x T p x , (1
div.p: where
div.formula: L p = ( p L p + L T p p )/2, p = diag(ξ p1 , ξ p2 , ..., ξ pN ), ξ p = (ξ p1 , ξ p2 , ..., ξ pN ) T > 0, satisfying ξ T p L p = 0, N i=1 ξ pi = 1.
div.p: Then, a(L p ) > 0. Similarly to the above two lemmas, the following two lemmas present some properties for the Laplacian matrix L of a signed digraph, which will be utilized for deducing the main results of this paper later.

Lemma 5: Suppose that L corresponds to a strongly connected, structurally balanced digraph, with adjacency matrix G. Then, ∃D ∈ D such that L D1 N = 0, and there is a positive vector ξ = (ξ 1 , ξ 2 , ..., ξ N ) T such that ξ T DL = 0. Denote = diag(ξ 1 , ξ 2 , ..., ξ N ). Then, > 0 and -1 > 0.

Proof: Since L corresponds to a strongly connected, structurally balanced digraph, it follows from Lemma 2 that ∃D ∈ D such that DG D has all nonnegative entries, which means that DL D corresponds to a strongly connected, positive digraph. It is easy to check that DL D1 N = 0 N×1 , which leads to L D1 N = 0 N×1 because D is invertible. Then, according to Lemma 3, there exists a positive vector ξ = (ξ 1 , ξ 2 , ..., ξ N ) T such that ξ T DL D = 0 1×N , which implies that ξ T DL = 0 1×N since D is invertible.
Lemma 6: For Laplacian matrix L corresponding to a strongly connected, structurally balanced digraph, define its general algebraic connectivity
div.formula: a(L) = min x T Dξ =0,x =0 x T Lx x T x ,(2)
div.p: where L = 1 2 (L + L T ), ξ and are defined in Lemma 5. Then a(L) > 0.
Proof: Similarly to the proof of Lemma 5, ∃D ∈ D such that DL D corresponds to a strongly connected, positive digraph. Then, according to Lemma 4, and since D = D, the following property holds:
div.formula: 0 < a(DL D) = min y T ξ =0,y =0
a(L) = min x T Dξ =0,x =0 x T Lx x T x = a(DL D) > 0.(3)
div.p: Before going on, some useful inequalities and lemmas concerning finite-time convergence are presented.
Lemma 7 [49]: For any given w i ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, ..., N, and ν > μ ≥ 1:
div.formula: N i=1 w ν i 1 ν ≤ N i=1 w μ i 1 μ ≤ N 1 μ -1 ν N i=1 w ν i 1 ν . (4)
div.p: Definition 3 [47], [48]: A function V : R m → R is homogeneous of degree l ≥ 0 with respect to a given m-tuple of positive coefficients r = (r 1 , ..., r m ) if
div.formula: V (λ r 1 x 1 , ..., λ r m x m ) = λ l V (x 1 , ..., x m ),(5)
div.p: where x 1 , ..., x m ∈ R and λ > 0.

Lemma 8 [47]: Suppose V 1 and V 2 are continuous realvalued functions on R m , homogeneous with respect to a given m-tuple of positive coefficients r = (r 1 , ..., r m ) of degree l 1 > 0 and l 2 > 0, respectively, and V 1 is positive definite. Then, for every x ∈ R m , min
Definition 4 [45], [46]:
div.formula: Consider the system ẋ(t) = f (x(t)), f (0) = 0, x(0) = x 0 , x ∈ R k .
div.p: The origin is said to to be globally finite-time stable if it is globally asymptotically stable and any solution x(t, x 0 ) reaches to origin in a finite time, that is x(t, x 0 ) = 0, ∀t ≥ T (x 0 ), where T : R k -→ R + ∪{0} is called the settling time. Furthermore, if the origin is globally finite-time stable and the settling time
div.formula: T (x 0 ) satisfies T (x 0 ) ≤ T max , ∀x 0 ∈ R k , where T max > 0.
div.p: Then, the origin is said to be globally fixed-time stable.
div.formula: Consider the system ẋ(t) = f (x(t)), f (0) = 0, x(0) = x 0 , x ∈ R k .
div.p: Suppose that there exists a radially unbounded, positive definite continuous function V (x) : R k → R, and two real numbers c > 0 and r ∈ (0, 1), such that
Then, the origin is a globally finite-time stable equilibrium of this system. In addition, the finite settling time T satisfies
div.formula: T ≤ V (x(0)) 1-r c(1-r) . Furthermore, if the continuous function V (x) satisfies V (x) + c 1 (V (x)) r 1 + c 2 (V (x)) r 2 ≤ 0, with c 1 , c 2 > 0 and 0 < r 1 < 1 < r 2 ,
div.p: then the origin is a globally fixedtime stable equilibrium, and the settling time T is bounded by T ≤

div.head: III. FINITE-TIME FIRST-ORDER BIPARTITE CONSENSUS
div.p: In this section, finite-time first-order bipartite consensus problem in the presence of disturbances on a directed signed network is studied. The dynamics of agent i is given by

where x i (t), u i (t), d i (x i , t) ∈ R represent the state, control input and disturbance, respectively. In the following, x i , u i and d i are used for simplicity. Definition 5: For the multi-agent system (7), the finite-time first-order bipartite consensus problem is said to be solved if there exist some control inputs u i and a finite settling time T > 0, such that
div.formula: lim t →T - |x i | -|x j | = 0,and
div.p: Furthermore, if the settling time T is independent of the initial states, then the first-order bipartite consensus problem is referred to as the fixed-time problem [51], [52]. Remark 3: If the agreement value is zero, i.e. x i = 0, i = 1, 2, .., N, the finite-time bipartite consensus problem reduces to the finite-time stabilization problem.

div.head: A. Finite-Time First-Order Bipartite Consensus Without Disturbance
div.p: Firstly, in this subsection, consider the nominal system without disturbance:
where ūi ∈ R is the control input to be designed. For system (9), the following general distributed protocol is proposed:
div.formula: ūi = -a N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [α] -b N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [β] ,(10)
div.p: where a, b, α and β are nonnegative parameters to be determined later. Let
div.formula: y i = N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j , y = [y 1 , ..., y N ] T , x = [x 1 , ...,
div.p: x N ] T . One then gets that y = Lx, and y ⊥ Dξ . Thus, the evolution of y satisfies ẏ = -a Ly [α] -bLy [β] .

The following theorem validates the control protocol (10). Theorem 1: Consider the multi-agent system (9) with control protocol (10), and choose a > 0, b = 0, and α ∈ (0, 1). If the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, then the finite-time bipartite consensus can be achieved. Otherwise, if the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, then the finitetime stabilization problem of the multi-agent system (9) can be solved with the control protocol (10).

Remark 4: Although for structurally unbalanced communication topology, the consensus problem degenerates to stabilization problem, it is still interesting because no agent could know whether the communication topology is structurally balanced or unbalanced. This situation could be taken as a comparison to show that structure does influence the finial convergence states.
Before giving a proof to Theorem 1, two useful lemmas are provided, for which detailed proofs are given in Appendix.

Lemma 10: Consider the Laplacian matrix L related to a strongly connected, structurally balanced digraph. Then, ∃D ∈ D such that DL D is a positive digraph Laplacian matrix. For given positive scalar a, α, and β with condition α = β, define the vector set (a, α, β) = {z : ∃y⊥Dξ and γ = γ (y) ≥ 0, s.t. z = ay [α] + γ y [β] , and z T z = 1}. Then,
div.formula: inf z∈(a,α,β) z T Lz = k 1 > 0,(12)
div.p: where L = (L + L T )/2, ξ and are defined in Lemma 5.

Remark 5: Consider the definition of z in Lemma 10, with a, α, and β fixed. It is clear that γ depends on the value of y. Thus γ (y) is adopted to indicate that γ depends on y. One should also notice that the positive value k 1 actually depends on the value of a, α, and β.

Lemma 11: Assume that the Laplacian matrix L corresponds to a strongly connected, structurally unbalanced digraph. Then, there exists a positive definite diagonal matrix P = diag( p 1 , p 2 , ..., p N ) such that P L + L T P > 0.
With the help of the above two lemmas, Theorem 1 is now proved.
Proof: [Proof for Theorem 1] Suppose the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced. Choose the Lyapunov function
div.formula: V = N i=1 ξ i α + 1 |y i | α+1 , (13
div.p: where ξ i is defined in Lemma 5. Taking the derivatives of V along the trajectories ( 11) with b = 0, one obtains

div.formula: L = 1/2(L + L T ), z = y [α] ∈ (1, α, β) with γ = 0, ȳ = y/||z|| 1 α
div.p: , and the last inequality is followed by Lemma 10.

div.p: The above analysis indicates that the bipartite consensus is achieved in finite time, and the settling time T 0 satisfies
. Suppose now the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced. Choose the following Lyapunov function for the consensus error system (9):
div.formula: V = N i=1 p i α + 1 |y i | α+1 , (16
div.p: where p i is defined in Lemma 11. By employing some similar analysis as those utilized above, one can prove that V reaches 0 in finite time, i.e. y i reaches 0 in finite time. Besides, y = Lx, and L is invertible if the strongly connected digraph is structurally unbalanced according to Remark 2, so one can conclude that the multi-agent system (9) is stabilized in finite time with the control protocol (10), and the settling time T0 is estimated as T0 ≤ V (Lx(0)) 1-r 1 c1 (1-r 1 ) , where c1 = aλ min ( L )((α + 1)/ p max ) r1 , r1 = 2α/(1 + α), L = 1 2 (P L + L T P), p max = max( p 1 , p 2 , ..., p N ), and P = diag( p 1 , p 2 , ..., p N ).

Remark 6: The above settling time T 0 and T0 depend on the initial values x(0). However, the control protocol (10) with a, b > 0 can ensure fixed-time convergence while the settling time is independent of the initial values. The following corollary verifies this observation.

Corollary 1: Consider the multi-agent system (9) with control protocol (10). Choose a, b > 0 and 0 < α < 1 < β. If the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, then the fixed-time bipartite consensus can be achieved. Otherwise, if the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, then the fixedtime stabilization problem of multi-agent system (9) can be solved with the control protocol (10).
Proof: Suppose the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced. Choose the Lyapunov function
div.formula: V = N i=1 ξ i a α + 1 |y i | α+1 + b β + 1 |y i | β+1 , (17

The above analysis indicates that the fixedtime bipartite consensus of multi-agent system (9) is achieved, and the settling time

div.head: B. Finite-Time First-Order Bipartite Consensus With Bounded Disturbances
div.p: With the above discussion on the nominal system (9), a class of sliding-mode control protocol is proposed in this subsection to solve the finite-time first-order bipartite consensus problem for the multi-agent system (7), which is influenced by disturbances. Before giving the main result, one assumption is needed.
Assumption 1: The disturbance d i (x i , t) in system ( 7) is assumed to satisfy the following condition:
where
div.formula: D i > 0 is a constant and || • || ∞ is the infinite norm of a vector, i = 1, 2, ..., N.
div.p: Design the following sliding-mode variables:
div.formula: s i = x i + r i , ṙi = a N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [α] +b N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [β] , (25
div.p: where a, b, α, and β are defined in (10), and accordingly the sliding-mode surface is

Theorem 2: Consider the multi-agent system (7) with Assumption 1 satisfied. Choose a > 0, b = 0, and α ∈ (0, 1) for the sliding-mode variables (25). If the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, then the sliding-mode surface (26) can be reached in finite time with the following sliding-mode control used:
div.formula: u i = ūi + u nd i , u nd i = -l i sign(s i ), (27
div.p: where ūi is defined in (10) and l i > D i . Thus, the finitetime bipartite consensus can be achieved. Otherwise, if the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, then the finite-time stabilization problem of multiagent system (7) can be solved with the control protocol (27).
Proof: Taking the derivative of s i along (7) with control laws (27) and (25) gives
div.formula: ṡi = d i -l i sign(s i ), i = 1, 2, ..., N. (28
div.p: Choose the Lyapunov function V = 1 2 s T s with s = [s 1 , ..., s N ] T , and take the derivative of V . One obtains
div.formula: V = N i=1 s i ṡi = N i=1 (s i d i -l i |s i |) ≤ N i=1 -(l i -D i )|s i | ≤ - l√ V , (29
div.p: where l = √ 2 min i=1,...,N {l i -D i }. It follows that V reaches 0 in finite time T d ≤ 2 √ V (s(0))/ l, which results in that all the states x i reach the sliding-mode surface (26) in finite time T d . Then, s i = ṡi = 0, i = 1, 2, ..., N, for t ≥ T d . Furthermore, ṡi = 0 means that the nominal system (9) holds thereafter. According to Theorem 1, the finite-time firstorder bipartite consensus can be reached if the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, and the finite-time first-order stabilization can be solved if the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced.

Corollary 2: Consider the multi-agent system (7) with Assumption 1 satisfied. Choose a, b > 0 and 0 < α < 1 < β for the sliding-mode variables (25). If the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, then the sliding-mode surface ( 26) can be reached in fixed time with the following sliding-mode control used:
div.formula: u i = ūi + u xd i , u xd i = -a i s [α i ] i -b i s [β i ] i -l i sign(s i ), (30
div.p: where ūi is defined in (10), a i , b i > 0, 0 < α i < 1 < β i , and l i > D i . Thus, the bipartite consensus can be achieved in fixed time. Otherwise, if the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, then the fixedtime stabilization problem of multi-agent system (7) can be solved with the control protocol (30).

div.p: It follows that V i reaches 0 in fixed time 1) . With similar arguments as in the proof for Theorem 2, one can prove the claims in this corollary.

div.head: IV. FINITE-TIME SECOND-ORDER BIPARTITE CONSENSUS
div.p: In this section, the finite-time second-order bipartite consensus problem with disturbances on a directed signed network is discussed. Suppose each agent is described by the following second-order dynamics:
div.formula: ẋi (t) = v i (t), vi (t) = u i (t) + di (x i , v i , t), i = 1, 2, ..., N,(32)
div.p: where x i (t), v i (t), di (x i , v i , t) ∈ R represent the position, velocity and disturbance of the i th agent, respectively, and u i (t) ∈ R is the control protocol for agent i . In the following, x i , v i , u i and di are used for simplicity.

Definition 6: For the multi-agent system (32), the finitetime second-order bipartite consensus problem is said to be solved if and only if there exist some control inputs u i , a finite settling time T > 0, and δ i ∈ {±1}, i = 1, 2, ..., N, such that
div.formula: lim t →T -|δ i • (x i , v i ) -δ j • (x j , v j )| = 0, δ i • (x i , v i ) = δ j • (x j , v j ), t ≥ T, i, j = 1, ..., N. (33
div.p: If the agreement value is zero, i.e. x i = v i = 0, i = 1, 2, .., N, the finite-time stabilization problem is solved.

div.head: A. Finite-Time Second-Order Bipartite Consensus Without Disturbance
div.p: In this subsection, the nominal system without disturbance is given by
where ūi (t) ∈ R is the control input to the nominal system. With a bit abuse of index notations (a, b, α, and β), consider the following control protocol for the nominal system (34):
div.formula: ūi = -a N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [α] -b N j =1 |G i j | v i -sign(G i j )v j [β] , (35
div.p: where a, b are some positive constants to be determined later, and α ∈ (0, 1], β = 2α 1+α . Denote x = [x 1 , ..., x N ] T , v = [v 1 , ..., v N ] T , and let e x = Lx and e v = Lv. Then, one obtains the error system ėx = e v , ėv = -a L(e x ) [α] -bL(e v ) [β] .

The following theorem provides a sufficient condition for achieving the finite-time second-order bipartite consensus. Theorem 3: Consider system (34) with controller (35). Assume that the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, a and b satisfy a(L)•b 2 > a, and α is chosen properly. Then, the finite-time secondorder bipartite consensus can be achieved. Besides, when the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, the finite-time second-order consensus can be achieved if λ min ( L ) • b 2 > a and α is chosen properly, where L = 1 2 (P L + L T P) and P is defined in Lemma 11. div.p: Secondly, it is easy to verify the following: 1. V (α 0 , e x , e v ) is homogeneous over (e x , e v ), with dilation (2, ..., 2, 1 + α 0 , ..., 1 + α 0 ) of degree 4;

Since L is invertible according to Remark 2, x and v reach 0 in finite time, which means that the finite-time second-order consensus is achieved. Furthermore, the settling time is estimated as T1 ≤ V α 0 , Lx(0), Lv(0)

). Remark 7: In Theorem 3, the existence of α 0 (or α 0 ) is essential, since it ensures the derivatives of the constructed homogeneous Lyapunov function V (or V ) be negative definite. This idea is inspired by the work [53], while it is more complicated here in the setting of multi-agent systems. Furthermore, [42] firstly proposed the concept called generalized algebraic connectivity of strongly connected networks with positive weights, which provides a general way to deal with directed networks. The Lyapunov function constructed here partly generates from this concept.

div.head: B. Finite-Time Second-Order Bipartite Consensus With Bounded Disturbances
div.p: With the discussion for the second-order nominal system (34) in the above subsection, it is ready to solve the finite-time second-order bipartite consensus problem for the multi-agent system (32), which is influenced by disturbances.
Assumption 2: [43], [50] The disturbances di (x i , , v i , t) in system (32) satisfy the following condition:
where Di > 0 is a constant and || • || ∞ is the infinite form of a vector, i = 1, 2, ..., N.
Design the following sliding-mode variables:
div.formula: si = v i + ri , ṙi = a N j =1 |G i j | x i -sign(G i j )x j [α] +b N j =1 |G i j | v i -sign(G i j )v j [β] ,(44)
div.p: where a, b, α, and β are defined in (35) and, accordingly, the sliding-mode surface is

Theorem 4: Consider the multi-agent system (7) with Assumption 2 satisfied. Choose a, b > 0, α ∈ (0, 1], and β = 2α 1+α for the sliding-mode variables (44). Then, the slidingmode surface ( 44) and ( 45) can be reached in finite time with the following sliding-mode controllers:
div.formula: u i = ūi + u d i , u d i = -li sign(s i ), (46
div.p: where ūi is defined in (35), and li > Di . Furthermore, when the communication topology is strongly connected and structurally balanced, the finite-time bipartite consensus of the multi-agent system (32) can be achieved if a(L) • b 2 > a and α is chosen as in Theorem 3. Otherwise, when the communication topology is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced, the finite-time stabilization problem of the multiagent system (32) can be solved if λ min ( L ) • b 2 > a, and α is chosen as in Theorem 3, where L = 1 2 (P L + L T P) and P is defined in Lemma 11.
Proof: Taking the derivative of si along (32) with controllers (46) and variables (44), one gets
div.formula: ṡi = di -li sign(s i ), i = 1, 2, ..., N. (47
div.p: Choose the Lyapunov function V = 1 2 s T s with s = [s 1 , ..., sN ] T , and then take the derivative of V . One obtains
div.formula: V = N i=1 si ṡi = N i=1 (s i di -li |s i |) ≤ N i=1 -( li -Di )|s i | ≤ - l√ V , (48
div.p: where l = √ 2 min i=1,...,N { li -Di }. It follows that V reaches 0 in finite time Td ≤ 2 V (s(0))/ l, which results in that all the states x i and v i reach the sliding-mode surface (45) and (44) in finite time Td . Thus, si = ṡi = 0, i = 1, 2, ..., N, for t ≥ Td . Furthermore, ṡi = 0 means that the nominal system (34) holds thereafter. According to Theorem 3, the finite-time secondorder bipartite consensus can be reached if the communication Remark 8: Notice that a positive graph is a special situation of a signed graph, so all the above conclusions can be drawn when the communication topology is a positive digraph.

div.head: V. SIMULATION EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, two examples are provided to verify the theoretical analysis. Consider a multi-agent system consisting of 5 agents, with the corresponding communication topologies illustrated in Fig. 1, where Fig. 1
, respectively.

div.head: A. Example 1
div.p: Consider the following first-order multi-agent system with bounded disturbances:

where the bound of the disturbances is D i = 1. Firstly, consider the communication topology shown in Fig. 1(a). The control protocol takes the form ( 27) with ( 10) and (25), and the parameters are chosen as a = 1, b = 0, α = 0.8, and l i = 1.5. Furthermore, randomly set the initial states as [x 1 (0), ..., x 5 (0)] = [1.1, -9.2, 4.5, -6, 10]. The trajectories of the 5 agents are shown in Fig. 2. One can observe that the bipartite consensus is achieved after about 40s. Furthermore, agents 1, 2 and 5 meet the same values, and agents 3 and 4 reach the opposite values, which is coincident with the fact that the agents in Fig. 1(a) can be divided into two clusters, V 1 = {1, 2, 5} and V 2 = {3, 4}, where the edges in each cluster are positive weighted, while the edges between the two clusters take negative weights. Accordingly, consider the fixed-time control protocol (30) with ( 10) and ( 25 Then, consider the communication topology shown in Fig. 1(b). The control protocol still takes the form (27) with (10) and (25), and the parameters are chosen as a = 1, b = 0, α = 0.8, and l = 1.5. Set randomly the initial states as [x 1 (0), ..., x 5 (0)] = [-8, 3, 7, -4, -6]. The trajectories of the 5 agents are shown in Fig. 4, which become stable after about 30s. Accordingly, consider the fixed-time control protocol (30) with ( 10) and ( 25), and the parameters are taken as a α i = 0.9, and β i = 1.1. Take the same initial conditions as [x 1 (0), ..., x 5 (0)] = [-8, 3, 7, -4, -6]. The trajectories of the 5 agents are shown in Fig. 5. It shows that all the agents reach stable after about 13s, which is faster than the finite-time control protocol above.

div.head: B. Example 2
div.p: Consider the following second-order multi-agent system with bounded disturbances:

where the bound of the disturbance is Di = 1. First, consider the communication topology depicted in Fig. 1(a). The control protocol takes the form ( 46) with ( 35) and ( 44 One can observe that all the agents achieve the second-order consensus after about 35s.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the finite-time bipartite consensus problem for signed digraphs has been studied. Some useful properties of signed digraphs have been revealed. One kind of nonlinear control protocol has been designed for first-order multiagent systems, which solves the finite-time bipartite consensus problem. Furthermore, with some properly chosen parameters, the proposed control protocol can ensure the first-order multi-agent system to achieve fixed-time bipartite consensus. Another homogeneity-based nonlinear control protocol has been designed for second-order multi-agent systems, to reach finite-time bipartite consensus for which the convergence time has been estimated.

Although the estimation of the settling time for secondorder multi-agent systems is given in an accurate mathematical formulation, it is not easy to compute. Thus, in the future, some efficient algorithms will be developed. Furthermore, multi-agent systems with nonlinear dynamics as well as some practical applications of bipartite consensus will be investigated. z T Lz = 0. Then, ∃{z l } ⊆ (a, α, β), s.t. lim l→∞ (z l ) T Lz l = 0. In addition, z l can be expressed as z l = a(y l ) [α] + γ l (y l ) [β] . Notice that ||z l || = 1, and 0 is the algebraically simple eigenvalue of L with D1 N being the corresponding eigenvector, there exists a subset -ε > 0. So the j th element of z l i takes the same sign as d j with l i being large enough. On the other hand, z l i = a(y l i ) [α] + γ l i (y l i ) [β] , one gets that y l i j take the same sign of d j , which makes Dy l i a positive vector. This is a contradiction with the fact that y T Dξ = 0. So, inf (
div.formula: {z l i } ⊆ {z l } such that z l i → 1 √ N D1 N or -1 √ N D1 N .
div.p: Before proving Lemma 11, a useful property is presented. Proposition 1: Suppose a signed digraph G is structurally unbalanced, strongly connected, and weight-balanced. Then, the Laplacian matrix L satisfies L + L T > 0.

Proof for Proposition 1: Denote the corresponding adjacency matrix and Laplacian matrix with G = G i j N×N and L, respectively. Let C r be the diagonal matrix with the i -th diagonal element C r i being
div.formula: N j =1 G i j . Let L = 1 2 (L + L T ) = C r -1 2 (G + G T ) = C r -G u .
div.p: It is easy to see that L = C r -G. One can also rewrite L = Cr + L u , where L u corresponds to the Laplacian matrix of the undirected graph G(G u ) generated by G u . Besides, Cr is the redundant diagonal matrix with its i -th diagonal element being C r i -1 2 j =1 |G i j + G j i | ≥ 0. If G i j G j i ≥ 0, i, j = 1, ..., N (called digon sign-symmetric), the result becomes Proposition 3 in [23]. In the following, just consider that digon sign-symmetry is not satisfied. Then, there exist i 1 = i 2 such that G i 1 i 2 G i 2 i 1 < 0. It is easy to see that C r i k -1

Consider L = p L. It is easy to check that L is the Laplacian matrix corresponding to a signed digraph Ḡ, which shares the same edge directions and signs of weights with the signed digraph G, except for the weight values. Furthermore, the signed digraph Ḡ is weight-balanced because of (52). Thus, according to Proposition 1, one has that p L + L T p > 0.

figure.figDesc: =1 |G i k j + G j i k | > 0, k = 1, 2.Since G is weight balanced, and not digon signsymmetric, Cr has at least one positive element. If G(G u ) is connected and structurally unbalanced, then L u > 0, which follows that L = L u + Cr > 0. If G(G u ) is connected and structurally balanced, then there exists D ∈ D such that DL u D corresponds to a positive graph. It also follows that L = D(D Cr D + DL u D)D > 0. Now consider the situation that G(G u ) is not connected. This could only happen when the node pair set X = (i, j ): |G i j | + |G j i | > 0, G i j + G j i = 0 is nonempty. Then G(G u ) can be divided into m connected components: G(G u 1 ), ..., G(G u m ). Denote the corresponding Laplacian matrices as L u i , i = 1, ..., m. Without loss of generality, one has L u = diag(L u 1 , ..., L u m ).Cr can be correspondingly rewritten as Cr = diag( Cr 1 , ..., Cr m ). It is easy to see that each G(G u i ) has at least one node that belongs to the endpoint of the node pair in set X. Thus each Cr i has at least one positive diagonal element. For each connected component, applying the above argument, one hasL u i + Cr i > 0, i = 1, ..., m. Then L = diag(L u 1 + Cr 1 , ..., L u m + Cr m ) > 0. This completes the proof.Suppose the digraph G is strongly connected but structurally unbalanced. Its adjacency matrix and Laplacian matrix are denoted by G and L, respectively. Then, define the corresponding positive digraph G p by G p i j = |G i j |, i, j = 1, 2, ..., N, which maintains the directions, but has nonnegative weights. Here, G p = (G p i j ) N×N is the adjacency matrix of G p . The Laplacian matrix L p of G p is defined correspondingly. Then, G p is a strongly connected digraph. According to Lemma 3 in[42], there exists a positive vector ξ p = (ξ p 1 , ξ p 2 , ..., ξ p N ) T such that L T p ξ p = 0. Let p = diag= 0 N = p L p 1 N .(
